title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the water seeping out of the ground in Northern Manhattan?

options.label: A
options.text: It's contaminated with heavy metals.

options.label: B
options.text: It's only available in the summer months.

options.label: C
options.text: You can drink it directly from your hands and be okay.

options.label: D
options.text: It's only found in areas with dense vegetation.

multiple-choice.question: How have the bridges crossing from the Bronx into Manhattan affected the northern dusky salamanders?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a physical barrier that prevents the salamanders from migrating.

options.label: B
options.text: They have introduced a new food source for the salamanders.

options.label: C
options.text: They have divided the salamander population, changing their evolutionary history.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no impact on the salamanders' behavior.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of setting up traps around New York City and the parks?

options.label: A
options.text: To capture and relocate animals that are a threat to the ecosystem.

options.label: B
options.text: To study animal behavior in natural habitats.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand how species, such as the white-footed mouse, adapt to urban environments.

options.label: D
options.text: To monitor population sizes of animals in the city.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the white-footed mouse significant in the context of urban ecology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an invasive species that is harming the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a native species that has been present for thousands of years, serving as a model to understand adaptation to urban environments.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a common species found only in forests and meadows outside the city.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a species found only in urban areas and is well adapted to city life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of sequencing thousands of genes from city mice and comparing them to thousands of genes from country mice?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand genetic differences between the two populations and their adaptation to urban environments.

options.label: B
options.text: To identify genetic factors contributing to disease in urban populations.

options.label: C
options.text: To study the evolutionary history of mice and their migration patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: To monitor population sizes and behavior of mice in different habitats.

multiple-choice.question: What does the Manhattan plot represent in the context of the study?

options.label: A
options.text: A graph showing genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: B
options.text: A graph showing population sizes of mice in different parks.

options.label: C
options.text: A graph showing behavior of mice in their natural habitat.

options.label: D
options.text: A graph showing environmental factors affecting mice in the city.

multiple-choice.question: What do the genes above the red line on the Manhattan plot primarily encode for?

options.label: A
options.text: Immune response to disease

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: Heavy-metal tolerance

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above, including immune response, metabolism, and heavy-metal tolerance.

multiple-choice.question: Why are researchers following the lives of individual mice in the wilds of New York City parks?

options.label: A
options.text: To study behavior of mice in their natural habitat.

options.label: B
options.text: To understand how genes identified in the study affect mice in the wild.

options.label: C
options.text: To monitor population sizes and migration patterns of mice in the city.

options.label: D
options.text: To identify genetic factors contributing to disease in urban populations.

multiple-choice.question: What do the mixed-up colors in the middle of the figure represent?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic differences between city and country mice.

options.label: B
options.text: Population sizes of mice in different parks.

options.label: C
options.text: Behavior of mice in their natural habitat.

options.label: D
options.text: Parks in the city still connected by strips of forest, allowing gene flow between mouse populations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author encouraging the audience to do?

options.label: A
options.text: Study animal behavior in natural habitats.

options.label: B
options.text: Understand how species adapt to urban environments through scientific research.

options.label: C
options.text: Look at their parks in a new way and appreciate the urban wildlife that inhabits them.

options.label: D
options.text: Monitor population sizes and migration patterns of animals in the city.

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: What is the main point of the passage about using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Complex vocabulary is always necessary for effective communication.

options.label: B
options.text: Every piece of literature should be written at a basic reading level to ensure understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: Using complex vocabulary can hinder effective communication if not understood by the audience.

options.label: D
options.text: The author prefers using complex vocabulary in their writing for its intellectual appeal.

multiple-choice.question: According to the passage, what is the main difference between writing for a captive audience and writing for a general audience?

options.label: A
options.text: The level of audience engagement and participation in the writing process.

options.label: B
options.text: The level of vocabulary and audience expectations regarding complexity and style.

options.label: C
options.text: The tone and style of writing used for each audience, such as formal or informal.

options.label: D
options.text: The purpose and scope of the writing, such as informative or entertaining.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to communicate effectively with their audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Use complex words to showcase vocabulary range and intellectual prowess.

options.label: B
options.text: Focus on using vivid descriptors for a specific audience to create a rich atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Be concise and avoid using unnecessary words or jargon that may confuse readers.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complex words and phrases to enhance writing.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the author believe that using complex vocabulary can be ineffective?

options.label: A
options.text: Complex words are difficult to pronounce and remember, making them impractical.

options.label: B
options.text: Complex words are not commonly used in conversation, making them seem out of place.

options.label: C
options.text: Complex words may not be understood by the target audience, leading to confusion.

options.label: D
options.text: Complex words are not necessary for effective communication, making them redundant.

multiple-choice.question: According to the passage, what is a reason why attention span continues to shrink across generations?

options.label: A
options.text: The increasing use of complex vocabulary in writing and media, leading to fatigue.

options.label: B
options.text: The increasing number of books being published every year, creating overwhelm.

options.label: C
options.text: The increasing level of education and literacy rates, raising expectations.

options.label: D
options.text: The increasing number of distractions competing for people's attention, causing fragmentation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to stand out in a crowded market?

options.label: A
options.text: Use as many complex words as possible to showcase skills and impress readers.

options.label: B
options.text: Focus on using vivid descriptors for a specific audience or niche to create a unique voice.

options.label: C
options.text: Be concise and avoid using unnecessary words or jargon to convey a clear message.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complex words and phrases to enhance writing and appear sophisticated.

multiple-choice.question: According to the passage, what is the author's opinion on the use of complex vocabulary in everyday language?

options.label: A
options.text: It is always effective in conveying a message and showcasing intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: It is never effective and should be avoided in favor of simpler words.

options.label: C
options.text: It is only effective when understood by the audience and used in context.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary and can be replaced with simpler words to ensure clarity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to write effectively for a general audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Use complex words and technical jargon to showcase expertise and authority.

options.label: B
options.text: Focus on using vivid descriptors and sensory details to create a rich atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: Be concise and avoid using unnecessary words or complex vocabulary to convey a clear message.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complex words and phrases to enhance writing and appear sophisticated.

multiple-choice.question: According to the passage, why does the author believe that Aerosmith would not have had a hit with "Ambulate This Direction?"

options.label: A
options.text: The song title is not catchy or memorable, making it hard to market.

options.label: B

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's advice for writers who want to write effectively in a world with shrinking attention spans?

options.label: A
options.text: Use complex words and technical jargon to engage readers and showcase expertise.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

options.label: B
options.text: Symbiosis

options.label: C
options.text: Adaptation

options.label: D
options.text: Commensalism
